Description: THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVES GOAL IS TO ENSURE THAT GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE AND DIVERSE SEED MIXES ARE ROUTINELY AVAILABLE TO SUPPORT THE RESTORATION AND POST-WILDFIRE REHABILITATION EFFORTS OF BLM BOTANISTS AND KSON PARTNERS WORKING IN OAK SAVANNA HABITATS.

THE ELK CREEK THERMAL REFUGE MAPPING PROJECT WILL MAP AREAS OF THERMAL REFUGIA IN APPROXIMATELY 10 TO 12 MILES OF COHO-BEARING STREAMS IN THE ELK CREEK WATERSHED. THERMAL DATA WILL BE ADDED TO THE COUNCILS GIS DATABASE OF HABITAT PARAMETERS OF THE STREAMS IN THE WATERSHED.

PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE CONSTRUCTION OF 4,160 FEET OF LIVESTOCK EXCLUSION FENCE, THE PLACEMENT OF LARGE WOOD AT TWO LOCATIONS ALONG THE CHANNEL MARGIN, AND THE PLANTING AND ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIVE VEGETATION IN 5 ACRES OF RIPARIAN AREA.

WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT BY MEMBERS OF NORTHWEST YOUTH CORP (NYC) YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULT CREWS TO FURTHER THE PUBLICS ENJOYMENT OF RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AT LOON LAKE CAMPGROUND AND THE BLUE RIDGE TRAIL SYSTEM. NYC WORK AT THE NORTH SPIT WILL HELP LANDS IN THE REGION RETAIN NATIVE HABITAT FOR FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT SPECIES. NYC CREWS WILL REMOVE DOWNED TREES AND STORM DEBRIS, MAINTAIN TWO CAMPGROUNDS, WEED THE HISTORIC HINSDALE GARDEN, REMOVE INVASIVE SPECIES AROUND MIGRATORY WATERWAYS FOR ANADROMOUS FISH, MAINTAIN HIKING AND MOUNTAIN BIKE TRAILS WITHIN THE BLUE RIDGE TRAIL SYSTEM, AND MAINTAIN COASTAL PRAIRIE AND OPEN DUNE HABITAT FOR SILVERY PHACELIA, WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER, AND WESTERN LILY.

THIS PROJECT WILL ENTAIL WORKING WITH BLM BOTANISTS AND OTHER LAND MANAGERS TO IDENTIFY RARE PLANT POPULATIONS THAT HAVE NOT BEEN MONITORED IN YEARS OR DECADES AND WHICH ARE LIKELY TO REQUIRE HABITAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS OR WERE IN FOREST MANAGEMENT PROJECT UNITS AND HAVE NOT BEEN MONITORED TO DETERMINE EFFICACY OF PROTECTION MEASURES.

WASSON FOREST INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL PURPOSE IS TO SUPPRESS INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES TO LIMIT THE PRODUCTION OF SEED THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ONSITE SEED BANK AND POTENTIALLY SPREAD ONTO ADJACENT FOREST LANDS. PRIMARY SPECIES TO BE TREATED ARE SCOTCH BROOM, HIMALAYAN BLACKBERRY, BULL THISTLE, AND FOXGLOVE. SUPPRESSION AND REMOVAL OF INVASIVES WILL ENCOURAGE NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES TO ESTABLISH WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA, CONTRIBUTING TO RIPARIAN AND UPLAND HABITAT QUALITY, STREAM SHADING, AND BANK STABILIZATION. PROJECT INTENDS TO REDUCE NON-NATIVE PLANTS ALONG 11.9 MILES OF ROAD NETWORK, TWO ACRES OF RIPARIAN, AND 91 ACRES OF UPLAND FOREST ON PRIVATELY MANAGED FOREST LAND. THE PROJECT AREA IS BORDERED BY OREGONS MOST RECENTLY DESIGNATED WILDERNESS, THE DEVILS STAIRCASE WILDERNESS AREA.

PROPOSED RESTORATION ACTIONS FOCUS ON LOWER STEEL CREEK AND INCLUDE LARGE WOOD AND BOULDER PLACEMENT, REMOVING FIVE SMALL CONCRETE WEIRS THAT ARE BARRIERS FOR JUVENILE FISH, AND TREATING AND PLANTING THE RIPARIAN AREA . RESTORATION WILL IMPROVE WATER QUALITY   QUANTITY AND FISH   WILDLIFE HABITAT IN A HOLISTIC AND WHOLE-WATERSHED APPROACH. THIS IS A FINAL PHASE OF A HOLISTIC WATERSHED RESTORATION APPROACH IN THE STEEL CREEK DRAINAGE THAT HAS BEEN SUPPORTED BY A COLLABORATIVE OF SEVERAL PARTNERS TO ADDRESS ALL PRIORITY LIMITING FACTORS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RE-ESTABLISH 62 ACRES OF RIPARIAN FLOODPLAIN FOREST ON CHAHALPAM BY SUPPORTING PLANT ESTABLISHMENT ACTIVITIES TO PROGRESS TOWARDS VEGETATION TARGETS AND DESIRED FUTURE CONDITIONS. THESE ACRES ARE COMPRISED OF SEVEN AGRICULTURAL FIELDS THAT WERE REMOVED FROM PRODUCTION. ALL ACRES HAVE BEEN REPLANTED USING THE RAPID RIPARIAN REVEGETATION (R3) METHOD WHERE NATIVE RIPARIAN HARDWOOD TREES AND SHRUBS ARE PLANTED IN HIGH DENSITIES TO ACHIEVE CANOPY COVER IN 5  7 YEARS. THIS METHODOLOGY MINIMIZES PER PLANT INVESTMENT TO ACHIEVE RAPID CANOPY CLOSURE, AND IS DESIGNED TO HAVE SHORT-TERM INVESTMENTS FOR LONG-TERM GAINS.

THE PROJECT ALLOWS FOR THE CONTINUATION OF THE PARTNERSHIP ESTABLISHED IN 2001, BETWEEN THE BLM AND THE LINN COUNTY JUVENILE DEPARTMENT.  THIS PARTNERSHIP ALLOWS LINN COUNTY YOUTH TO COMPLETE THEIR REQUIRED COMMUNITY SERVICE HOURS, ALLOWING THEM TO GAIN VALUABLE EXPERIENCES IN FOREST FUELS REDUCTION, NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL, CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE, ALONG WITH OTHER BLM RESOURCE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES.  THIS WORK WILL ENHANCE THE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR VISITORS OF THESE RESOURCE AREAS BY ENSURING ONGOING MAINTENANCE IS COMPLETED AND SAFETY HAZARDS ARE ADDRESSED AND CORRECTED.

PROMOTING RECOVERY OF BADLY BURNED WATERSHED, DETERMINE HOW BEST TO PERFORM EFFECTIVE, TIMELY RESTORATION AND COLLECTION OF THERMAL INFRARED, HIGH RESOLUTION, AND NATURAL COLOR ORTHOIMAGERY ON OVER 11 MILES OF ROCK CREEK. LONG-TERM SUMMER STREAM REFERENCE TEMPERATURE MONITORING TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE THREE MORE YEARS OF DATA FOR THIS PROJECT, AND THE EXPANDED NORTH UMPQUA ANALYSIS, CONTINUING A WELL-USED PROJECT AIDING IN SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT IN THE UMPQUA BASIN. RESTORE AND MAXIMIZE THE NATURAL PRODUCTION OF COHO SALMON, STEELHEAD, CUTTHROAT TROUT AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. RESTORE CHANNEL MORPHOLOGY AND RECONNECT THE FLOODPLAIN. RESTORE AND REHABILITATE THE AQUATIC HABITAT AFTER THE DEVASTATING ARCHIE CREEK FIRE THAT KILLED BETWEEN 80 TO 100  OF THE RIPARIAN VEGETATION AND TREES.

COLLABORATION WITH THE BLM TO EXPAND RIPARIAN REFORESTATION EFFORTS IN THE UPPER NEHALEM WATERSHED BY MAINTAINING, INTER-PLANTING AND EXPANDING THE RESTORATION FOOTPRINT TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR T E SPECIES. THE PROJECT SITES ON BLM LAND, THE VERNONIA SCHOOL CAMPUS, AND OTHER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PROPERTY ARE LOCATED WITHIN A GREATER NETWORK OF BASIN WIDE WATERSHED HEALTH AND NATIVE SALMON POPULATION RECOVERY PROJECTS.

THE GOAL IS TO ESTABLISH AND MAINTAIN LIVE WATER QUALITY DATA AT STREAM GAGE  1710032 NEAR WINSTON ON THE SOUTH UMPQUA RIVER FOR AT LEAST THREE YEARS. THIS WOULD PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING DATA EVERY 15 MINUTES FOR TEMPERATURE, TURBIDITY, PH, DISSOLVED OXYGEN, CONDUCTIVITY, AND NITRATE. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO INFORM THE PUBLIC, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND SCIENTISTS ABOUT THE EVER-CHANGING CONDITIONS OF THE RIVER. FUNDS WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO DOUGLAS COUNTY, WHICH WILL CONTRACT WITH USGS TO ADD, MAINTAIN, AND SERVICE EQUIPMENT TO MEASURE AND REPORT WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS EVERY 15 MINUTES. THE CURRENT PARAMETERS BEING REPORTED ARE STREAMFLOW AND GAGE HEIGHT AT THEIR EXISTING STREAM GAGE NEAR WINSTON, OREGON. USGS WILL INSTALL A YSI MULTIPARAMETER EXO2 SONDE WITH THE CALIBRATED PROBES ATTACHED FOR TEMPERATURE, TURBIDITY, PH, DISSOLVED OXYGEN, CONDUCTIVITY, AND NITRATE. THEY USE NATIONALLY APPROVED METHODS AND PROTOCOLS. PROVIDING CONTINUOUS, LIVE WATER QUALITY DATA FOR THE SOUTH UMPQUA RIVER THAT OTHERWISE DOES NOT EXIST.

MCWC PLANS TO INCREASE PRODUCTION OF GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE NATIVE PLANT MATERIAL TO BE UTILIZED AT RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THE REGION, INCLUDING ON AND ADJACENT TO FEDERAL LANDS. ADDITIONALLY, PLANT PRODUCTION MATERIALS, ADDITIONAL STAFF TIME, AND CONTRACTED SERVICES FUNDING WILL EXPAND OUR PRODUCTION TO INCLUDE NECTAR AND HOST PLANTS FOR THE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (OSB) TO BE PLANTED AT OSB RESTORATION SITES SUCH AS AT BLMS YAQUINA HEAD OUTSTANDING NATURAL AREA.
ORWA SRS RIPARIAN REVEGETATION AND COHO MONITORING
ORWA SRS FISH CREEK TRIBUTARY ENHANCEMENT AND WATERSHED RESILIENCE
ORWA SRS LONG TOM FISH PASSAGE AND  FLOODPLAIN RESTORATION
ORWA SRS PROVOLT RECREATION SITE INVASIVE-NOXIOUS WEED REMOVAL

WHILE SOUTHWEST OREGON HOSTS MANY RARE AND ENDEMIC PLANT SPECIES, MOST OF THESE SPECIES DO NOT HAVE WELL ESTABLISHED POPULATION TRENDS OR HABITAT QUALITY DATA. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH BASELINE MONITORING DATA FOR RARE PLANT POPULATIONS IN THE MEDFORD DISTRICT. THIS WILL LEAD TO HABITAT THREAT ASSESSMENTS THAT WILL INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SUCH AS NOXIOUS WEED TREATMENTS, RESTORATIVE THINNING, PRESCRIBED BURNING, OUT PLANTING AUGMENTATION, AND OR CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION.THIS PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVES RARE PLANT MONITORING NETWORK OF SOUTHWESTERN OREGON, WHICH INCLUDES A GROWING NUMBER OF VOLUNTEER PLANT ENTHUSIASTS WHO WANT TO BE INVOLVED IN INFORMING THE MANAGEMENT OF RARE PLANTS AND THEIR HABITATS. IT WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHO VALUE PUBLIC LANDS AND THE SPECIES THEY HOST TO VISIT RARE PLANT SITES, MEANINGFULLY CONTRIBUTE TO DATA COLLECTION, AND ENGAGE WITH THE GATHERING OF SCIENCE THAT WILL INFORM CONSERVATION ACTIONS SUCH AS PRESCRIBED BURNING, RESTORATIVE THINNING, AND WEED TREATMENTS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE HABITAT AT OAK BASIN PRAIRIES ACEC (OAK BASIN) FOR TWO LISTEDSPECIES AND ONE SPECIES OF CONCERN (SOC): FENDERS BLUE BUTTERFLY (ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI, ENDANGERED),KINCAIDS LUPINE (LUPINUS OREGANUS, THREATENED) AND HITCHCOCKS BLUE-EYED GRASS (SISYRINCHIUM HITCHCOCKII, SOC).TO ACHIEVE PROJECT GOALS, AN INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT APPROACH (MECHANICAL, CHEMICAL AND PHYSICAL) WILL BE USEDTO REMOVE INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, KINCAIDS LUPINE AND HITCHCOCKS BLUE-EYED GRASS POPULATIONS WILL BE AUGMENTED ORINTRODUCED, ENCROACHING CONIFERS WILL BE REMOVED, AND THE PROJECT SITE WILL BE SURVEYED TO ASSESS BASELINE CONDITIONSAND EFFICACY OF TREATMENTS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES FOR OAK BASIN ARE: 1) INCREASE THE AREA OF BLM-OWNED PRAIRIES THROUGHTHE REMOVAL OF ENCROACHING CONIFERS  2) DECREASE THE ABUNDANCE OF NON-NATIVE SPECIES  3) ESTABLISH DIVERSE NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING SPECIES OF CONCERN AND NATIVE BUTTERFLY NECTAR AND HOST PLANTS  4) MONITOR THE EFFICACY OFRESTORATION TREATMENTS AND SURVEY THE LOWER OAK BASIN KINCAIDS LUPINE POPULATION AND 5) DEVELOP AND MAINTAINSTRONG PARTNERSHIPS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS.
ORWA SRS RESTORATIVE PROJECT PAYBACK

THE TABLE ROCKS PROVIDE TWO OF THE MOST POPULAR HIKING TRAILS IN THE ROGUE VALLEY  WITH EVER INCREASING USE THE TRAILS NEED ONGOING MAINTENANCE WHICH IS DIFFICULT DUE TO SOME VERY STEEP SECTIONS THAT DO NOT PROVIDE PROPER DRAINAGE AND POOR EQUIPMENT ACCESS  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A MORE SUSTAINABLE AND EASIER TRAIL TO MAINTAIN AT UPPER TABLE ROCK

UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF BLM STAFF, THREE NORTHWEST YOUTH CORPS (NYC)TEEN CREWS WILL CARRY OUT1,229.25 HOURS OF WORK ON RECREATION SITE AND TRAIL MAINTENANCE, AND FENCE BUILDING AT TRAILS AND RECREATION SITES IN JOSEPHINE COUNTY ON BLM LANDS. AREAS INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO ROGUE RIVER NRT AND GRAYBACK MOUNTAIN TRAIL. CREWS MAY ALSOWORK ON KERBY PEAK TRAIL AND CATHEDRAL HILLS TRAILS. MILESTONES INCLUDE 20 MILES OF TRAIL MAINTENANCE.

PROJECT GOALS ARE: PRODUCE A PEER-REVIEWED PAPER IDENTIFYING BREEDING GROUND LIMITATIONS TO THE OREGON VESPER SPARROW (NEST SUCCESS AND PRODUCTIVITY, AND HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS); PRODUCE AN ASSOCIATED SUMMARY DOCUMENT FOR BLM MANAGERS THAT HIGHLIGHTS POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS; GIVE A PRESENTATION TO THE MEDFORD DISTRICT LEADERSHIP TEAM, BIOLOGISTS, AND OTHER INTERESTED STAFF, FOLLOWED BY A FIELD TRIP TO THE LOCAL STUDY SITES; HOST A PUBLIC PRESENTATION (E.G. PUB TALK) AND ASSOCIATED FIELD TRIP TO RAISE AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF BLM LANDS FOR THIS IMPERILED SPECIES; AND PRODUCE AS SERIES OF SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, BLOGS, AND WEB CONTENT THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THE PROJECT.

PERFORM ANNUAL MAINTENANCE (WEED WHACKING AND BRUSH TRIMMING) FOR THE STERLING MINE DITCH (SMDT) AND JACK-ASH TRAILS IN JACKSON COUNTY, OR TO ENSURE SAFE ACCESS TO THESE TRAILS FOR RECREATIONAL USERS.THIS MAINTENANCE WILL REMOVE ENCROACHING VEGETATION, MAINTAINING THE TRAIL CORRIDOR AND IMPROVING SIGHT LINES AROUNDCURVES. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE GRADING AND GRAVEL CAPPING AT TWO TRAILHEAD PARKING AREAS AND INSTALLINGINFORMATION KIOSKS AT THREE TRAILHEADS ON THE JACK-ASH TRAIL.

TO PROVIDE AN INCREASED TRAJECTORY FOR ECOLOGICAL UPLIFT BY ADDRESSING IMPAIRED FISHPASSAGE. WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS BY REMOVAL OF UNDERSIZED CULVERTS AT THREE SITES AND REPLACEMENT WITH BRIDGES THATMEET ALL STATE AND FEDERAL FISH PASSAGE CRITERIA. WE WILL ALSO REMOVE 7 INSTREAM CONCRETE STRUCTURES ASSOCIATED WITHTHESE UNDERSIZED CULVERTS.

THE OBJECTIVE OF PROPAGATING AND DISTRIBUTING >50,000 PLANTS A YEAR SUPPORTS NORP'S MISSION OF BEING A SOURCE OF COASTALLY ADAPTED, GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE NATIVE PLANT MATERIAL TO RESTORATION PARTNERS. NORP MEMBERS UTILIZE TEP'S PLANT MATERIAL IN APPROXIMATELY 50 RESTORATION PROJECTS ANNUALLY THAT MEET MULTIPLE DOI RESOURCE OBJECTIVES INCLUDING THE FOLLOWING: REESTABLISH NATIVE SPECIES; RESTORE, MAINTAIN, AND IMPROVE WILDLIFE AND FISH HABITAT, WATERSHEDS, AND FOREST ECOSYSTEM HEALTH; CONTROL NOXIOUS AND EXOTIC WEEDS; AND CONSERVATION EDUCATION. SUPPORT IS REQUESTED FOR 12-16 MONTHS TO FUND OVER 6000 HRS OF YOUTH LABOR, THEREBY ENSURING THE AVAILABILITY OF PLANTS TO MEET OUR GOAL OF SUSTAINING A NATIVE PLANT MATERIAL INVENTORY FOR PARTNERS TO RESTORE 200 ACRES AND 15 MILES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT ANNUALLY.

THE ROGUE NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP (RNPP) IS SEEKING FUNDING FOR A NEW PROGRAM ENTITLED THE ROGUE BASIN NATIVE SEED COOPERATIVE (RBNSC). THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO ENHANCE NATIVE SEED PRODUCTION THROUGH FARMER TECHNICAL AND MATERIAL SUPPORT PERTAINING TO SEED HARVEST, CLEANING, AND STORAGE, WHICH WILL RESULT IN MORE EFFICIENT AND COST-EFFECTIVE SEED PRODUCTION FOR SPECIFIC BLM RESTORATION PROJECTS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES, INCLUDING ESTABLISHING A PART-TIME COOPERATIVE COORDINATOR POSITION AND ORGANIZING A SHARED EQUIPMENT LIBRARY, WILL AID IN NATIVE PLANT AND WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION BY ALLOWING FOR INCREASED LOCAL NATIVE SEED PRODUCTION FOR USE ON BLM PROJECT SITES.

THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO RESTORE MEADOW HABITAT WITH PREVIOUSLY CONFIRMED MARDON SKIPPER OCCUPANCY, AND MONITOR MARDON SKIPPER POPULATIONS FOR PROJECT EFFECTIVENESS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) RESTORE NATURAL HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION OF WET MEADOWS 2) PROTECT HABITAT FROM ONGOING DEGRADATION AND 3) REPLACE NOXIOUS WEEDS WITH NATIVE PLANT SPECIES NECESSARY FOR MARDONS AS HOST AND NECTAR RESOURCES 4) COLLECT MARDON SKIPPER POPULATION DATA. THE GOAL AND ASSOCIATED OBJECTIVES WILL FURTHER THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVE'S MISSION TO FACILITATE THE RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION OF NATIVE SPECIES HABITAT THROUGH PARTNERSHIP AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. TO ADVANCE THIS MISSION, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TO FACILITATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR THE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF RESTORATION ACTIONS IN WET PRAIRIE HERBACEOUS PLANT COMMUNITIES, AND WILL MEET DOI PRIORITIES TO PROVIDE COMMUNITY-BASED SOLUTIONS TO PRESSING PUBLIC LANDS CHALLENGES, INCLUDING WILDLAND FIREPREVENTION, WATERSHED RESTORATION, MANAGEMENT OF SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND CONTROL OF NOXIOUS WEEDS. SUPPORT IS REQUESTED TO HELP MEET BLM OBJECTIVES TO ENHANCE MARDON SKIPPER HABITAT AND CONTINUE LONG-TERM SPECIES MONITORING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL IS TO PROVIDE KEY LONG-TERM (10 YEARS AFTER TREATMENT IMPLEMENTATION) MONITORING INFORMATION TO MEASURE OBJECTIVES RELATED TO THE JOHNSON AND FRANKLIN RESTORATION FORESTRY PRINCIPLES ON THE PILOT JOE PROJECT IN THE MIDDLE APPLEGATE. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOR FOLLOW-UP DATA COLLECTION AT THE COLLABORATIVELY DEVELOPED PLOTS AND PHOTO POINTS ON PILOT JOE, DATA ANALYSIS AND SUMMARY REPORT TO COMPLEMENT THE INITIAL PILOT JOE MULTI-PARTY MONITORING EFFORT AND HELP DETERMINE THE LONG-TERM IMPLICATIONS FOR THE ECOLOGICAL PROJECT OBJECTIVES:1. INCREASE FORESTAND ECOSYSTEM RESISTANCE AND RESILIENCE.2. INCREASE SPATIAL HETEROGENEITY TO BENEFIT BIODIVERSITY AND SPECIES OF CONCERNAT THE STAND AND LANDSCAPE SCALE.3. CONSERVE AND IMPROVE NORTHERN SPOTTED OWL HABITAT THROUGH LSEA (LATE SUCCESSIONAL EMPHASIS AREA) DESIGN. RESULTS WILL INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT AROUND THESE ECOLOGIC FORESTRY CONCEPTS THAT WERE CARRIED FORWARD INTO THE SOUTHWESTERN OREGON RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN DRY FOREST LAND USE ALLOCATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A 350 FEET RIPARIAN FOREST BUFFER WITH MATURE OVERSTORY UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE PROJECT WITHIN A WIDE VALLEY WITH LATERAL CHANNEL MIGRATION.THERE IS PROXIMITY TO COLDER WATER HABITAT UPSTREAM IN THE MAINSTEM, AND ENTRY OF A COOL-WATER TRIBUTARY,SODA CREEK WITHIN A HALF MILE OF UPSTREAM END OF THE PROJECT. THE WATER QUALITY RESTORATION PLAN REPORT FROM MEDFORD DISTRICT OF BLM (2006) FOUND SODA CREEK 7-DAY AVERAGE MAXIMUM TEMPERATURE AT 67.7 DEGREES (1994-2003). THE OWRD 14240800 HYDRO-STATION, LOCATED 1 MILE UPSTREAM, REGISTERS MAXIMUM WATER TEMPERATURES OF 64.4 - 68 DEGREES DURING LATE JULY THROUGH MID-AUGUST (2015-2019), CRITICAL OVER-SUMMER PERIODS FOR JUVENILE SALMONIDS. ALTHOUGH TEMPERATURES OCCASIONAL EXCEED REGULATORY TARGETS FOR SALMONID REARING, TEMPERATURES ARE WITHIN THE RANGE THAT RESTORATION ACTIONS WILL HAVE POSITIVE EFFECTS ON JUVENILE SALMONID SURVIVAL AND FITNESS. PART OF THE LONG-TERM STRATEGY IS TO BUILD CONTIGUOUS ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT WILL REDUCE CRITICAL SUMMER REARING TEMPERATURES INTO THE OPTIMAL BIOLOGICAL RANGE THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE SOUTH FORK LITTLE BUTTE CREEK DRAINAGE.WE PROPOSE A COMBINATION OF RESTORATION ACTIONS THAT WILL RESULT IN SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL UPLIFT AT THIS LOCATION. THESE ACTIONS WILL RESTORE CRITICAL STREAM PROCESSES AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND HABITAT CONDITIONS WITH INCREASED FLOOD PLAIN INTERACTION. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY:- PLACING LARGE WOOD AT 16 STRATEGIC LOCATIONS THROUGHOUT 0.6 MILES OF THE PROJECT LENGTH, INCLUDING ENHANCEMENT OF 0.35 MILES OF WINTER, SECONDARY CHANNELS,- REHABILITATING 9.4 ACRES OF RIPARIAN FOREST OVER THE COURSE OF FIVE GROWING SEASONS TO RECOVER THE NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITY THROUGH NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL, NATURAL RECRUITMENT OF NATIVE SPECIES, AND PLANTING OF NATIVE NURSERY STOCK,- PROTECTING THE ENTIRE WITH CONSTRUCTION OF 0.25 MILES OF WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY LIVESTOCK EXCLUSION FENCE TO ADD TO THE EXISTING 0.4 MILES OF FENCE.

YOUTH WILL ENGAGE IN EFFORTS TOWARD THESE FIVE GOALS: 1) NOXIOUS PLANT REMOVAL - SPECIFIC NOXIOUS WEEDS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED WITH SPECIFIC SITES TARGETED FOR REMOVAL. MEASURING SQUARE FEET OR ACREAGE OF REMOVAL IS TANGIBLE AND A GREAT EXPERIENCE FOR YOUTH. YOUTH LEARN CONSERVATION, ECOLOGY, AND MANAGEMENT, AND IDENTIFYING THE VALUE OF AND PROPER WAYS TO REMOVE NOXIOUS PLANTS, AND LEARN THE VALUE IN THE RETURN OF NATIVE SPECIES. 2) GUERRILLA CAMPSITES AND GARBAGE REMOVAL -SPECIFIC SITES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED FOR REMOVAL OF GARBAGE, AND TEACHING YOUTH ABOUT THE "RETURN TO THE FOREST" IS AN ESSENTIAL ASPECT OF THIS TASK. MEASURING OUTCOMES ARE SIMPLE IN COUNTING THE NUMBER OF SITES AND ACTIONS TAKEN. ALL GARBAGE REMOVED WOULD BE CATEGORIZED, WEIGHED OR MEASURED. 3) INFRASTRUCTURE MAINTENANCE - EACH SITE HAS SPECIFIC TASKS REQUIRED TO RETIRE SITES FOR THE WINTER, OPEN SITES FOR THE SPRING, AND PROVIDE ROUTINE MAINTENANCE. OUTCOMES ARE MEASURED THROUGH IDENTIFICATION OF SPECIFIC TASKS PERFORMED, TIME ENGAGED, AND POSITIVE PROGRAM OUTCOME AS A RESULT OF THE TASK COMPLETION. 4) TRAIL MAINTENANCE - SANDY RIDGE AND MOLALLA CORRIDOR TRAILS SITE SPECIFIC REPAIR, MODIFICATION, DRAINAGE MAINTENANCE, AND TREAD WORK. SPECIFIC MEASUREMENTS ARE LENGTH OF TRAILS MAINTAINED AND TASKS PERFORMED.
ORWA SRS GLOVER ESTUARY AND PARADISE CREEK TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND DESIGN
ORWA SRS SMALL STREAM FUNCTIONAL MONITORING FOR RESTORATION EFFECTIVENESS

THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS MULTIPLE ISSUES ON BLM AND TRIBAL LAND, INCLUDING IMPROVING THE ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION OF FOREST AND RIPARIAN AREAS (THROUGH INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL AND NATIVE PLANT PROPAGATION AND PLANTING) AND INCREASED SAFETY AND ACCESS FOR THE PUBLIC (THROUGH TRAIL AND RECREATION AREA MAINTENANCE AND IMPROVEMENT). INCREASING THE EMPLOYABILITY OF AT-RISK AND LOWINCOME LANE COUNTY YOUTH THROUGH INVOLVEMENT IN SERVICE-LEARNING WORK PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON FOREST RESTORATION AND RECREATION AREA MANAGEMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THESE PROJECTS WILL INTRODUCE YOUTH TO LOCAL PUBLIC LAND USE AND MULTIPLE BLM CAREER PATHWAYS.

MAINTAIN EXISTING TWELVE MILES OF TRAIL AT ALSEA FALLS TRAIL SYSTEM AND BUILD AN ADDITIONAL 2 MILES OF NEW BLACK DIAMOND MOUNTAIN BIKE TRAIL TO FURTHER ENHANCE THE USER EXPERIENCE. THE NEW TRAIL, NAMED CHUTES AND BOULDERS, WILL BE DIRECTIONAL AND GRAVITY-FED, DESCEND UP TO 900 VERTICAL FEET, AND WILL FEATURE A VARIETY OF NATURAL OBSTACLES AND TECHNICAL TRAIL FEATURES. CURRENTLY, 1.5 MILES OF THE 3.5 TOTAL MILES OF TRAIL IS ALREADY CONSTRUCTED, AND THE WORK OUTLINED IN THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE LAST 2 MILES NECESSARY TO COMPLETE ITS CONSTRUCTION. APPROXIMATELY 75% OF THE TRAIL WILL BE HAND-BUILT BY EXPERIENCED CREWS TO OPTIMIZE THE NATURAL TERRAIN AND TO PROVIDE THE DISTINCT NATURAL CHARACTER UPON WHICH A DOWNHILL MOUNTAIN BIKE TRAIL EXPERIENCE IS DEPENDENT. PORTIONS OF THE TRAIL WILL BE MACHINE-BUILT TO OPTIMIZE AREAS WHERE THE OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE TRAIL FLOW AND/OR TO ACCOMMODATE FOR DIFFICULT BUILD CONDITIONS. THE TRAIL WILL BE MANAGED TO PROVIDE DIRECTIONAL TRAVEL AND WILL BE CLOSED TO UPHILL RIDERS AS WELL AS OTHER NON-MOTORIZED RECREATIONISTS. THESE MANAGEMENT CONTROLS WILL ENSURE THAT THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE WILL BE OPTIMIZED FOR RIDER CHALLENGE AND FLOW.
OR/WA SRS CHENEY CREEK LARGE WOOD PROJECT

REHABILITATE TRAMPLED BOTANICAL RESOURCES WITHIN THE BLM ROUGH & READY AREA OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN TO RESTORE NATIVE PLANT LANDSCAPES AND PROVIDE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR INCLUSIVE RECREATIONAL ENJOYMENT AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. RESTORING NATIVE BOTANICAL SPECIES WITHIN BLM AREAS SET ASIDE DUE TO CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS IS A HIGH PRIORITY. IN ADDITION, PROVIDING WHEELCHAIR ACCESS TO PUBLIC LANDS ENSURES INCLUSIVE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO A MORE DIVERSE PUBLIC. THIS PROJECT'S INTENT IS TO BRING RELEVANT BOTANICAL REHABILITATION AND INCREASE WHEELCHAIR ACCESS TO PUBLIC LANDS.

CONCERNS WITHIN ALL THESE AREAS INCLUDE HIGH DENSITIES OF SMALL TREES (BOTH HARDWOODS AND CONIFERS), HIGH SURFACE AND LADDER FUEL LOADS, AND/OR ABUNDANCE OF DOWNED OR STANDING DEAD WOOD. INITIAL TREATMENTS IN ALL UNITS INVOLVE THE REDUCTION OF SURFACE AND LADDER FUELS BY MECHANICALLY CUTTING MAINLY NONCOMMERCIAL TREES AND SHRUBS. FOLLOWING INITIAL CUTTING, CREWS WILL HAND PILE ACTIVITY FUELS TO ENABLE SUBSEQUENT PILE-BURNING. DESIGN SPECIFICATIONS INCLUDE STRUCTURAL, SPATIAL, AND COMPOSITIONAL DIVERSITY RELATING TO OVERALL FOREST HEALTH AND RESILIENCE. IMPLEMENTERS WILL UTILIZE PRINCIPLES OF VARIABLE DENSITY THINNING, THINNING FROM BELOW, AND RADIAL THINNING DURING TREATMENTS. PRESCRIPTIONS MIMIC THE EFFECTS OF LOW TO MODERATE SEVERITY WILDFIRE SO THAT FIRE CAN BE REINTRODUCED SAFELY INTO THIS ECOSYSTEM AFTER MORE THAN A CENTURY OF EXCLUSION.TREATMENTS WILL RESULT IN TREE, STAND, AND FOREST LANDSCAPE RESILIENCE TO WILDFIRES. CUTTING AND PILING TREATMENTS ON THE 80 ACRES OF BLM LANDS WILL BE DELIVERED THROUGH AN EXISTING OWEB FIP AWARD.PROJECT BENEFITS: THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LARGER ROGUE FOREST RESTORATION INITIATIVE WHOSE GOALS INCLUDE INCREASING THE PROPORTION OF OPEN DRY-TYPE FOREST HABITAT AND REDUCING THE RISK OF WILDFIRE TO FOREST HABITAT AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES FROM CURRENT LEVELS BY 50 PERCENT WHERE THE ROGUE BASIN STRATEGY APPROACH AND TOOLS ARE FULLY IMPLEMENTED. THE RFRI WILLIAMS PROJECT HAS DEELOPED 274 ACRES OF RESTORATION TREATMENTS ON BOTH BLM AND ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS. OWEB AND NRCS FUNDING WILL COMPLETE ALL CUTTING, PILING AND BURNING ON PRIVATE LANDS. THIS TITLE II FUNDING FROM BLM PROVIDES THE FINAL FUNDING NEED TO COMPLETE THE PILE BURNING ON BLM LANDS IN THE PROJECT.

THE JOSEPHINE COUNTY FORESTRY DEPARTMENT HAS BEEN SPONSORING A TREE PLANT FOR THE AREA YOUTH SINCE 1989 ON ELK LANE AND STRINGER GAP ROAD JUST OUTSIDE OF GRANTS PASS. EACH YEAR APPROXIMATELY 1,000 KIDS INGRADES KINDERGARTEN TO 8TH GRADE FROM 18 AREA SCHOOLS AND YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS (E.G. BOY SCOUTS, GIRL SCOUTS, 4-H YOUNG MARINES) GET AN OPPORTUNITY TO PLANT TREE SEEDLINGS OF MIXED SPECIES IN A FOREST ENVIRONMENT. CHILDREN ARE GIVEN INSTRUCTIONS, ASSISTANCE IN PLANTING ALONG WITH DISCUSSION ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT, TREE IDENTIFICATION, FORESTRY, AND GOOD STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES FROM FORESTERS FROM THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY, COUNTY EXTENSION SERVICE AND JOSEPHINE COUNTY.THE CHILDREN ARE PROVIDED WITH PONDEROSA PINE, SUGAR PINE, AND DOUGLAS-FIR TREE SEEDLINGS, PLANTING BAGS, KRAFT PAPER MULCH TO PREVENT VEGETATION IN-GROWTH DIRECTLY AROUND THE SEEDLINGS, AND VEXAR TUBES TO PREVENT BROWSE FROM WILDLIFE. THE SAME PARCEL OF LAND HAS BEEN USED FOR THE YOUTH TREE PLANT THE LAST 32 YEARS. DURING THE TREE PLANT, LOCAL VOLUNTEERS GIVE CHILDREN TRACTOR RIDES THROUGHOUT THE PARCEL WHERE THEY CAN SEE STAND DYNAMICS IN ACTION (HOW THE PLANTED STANDS OF DIFFERENT AGES HAVE GROWN AND CHANGED OVERTIME). THE CHILDREN ARE ALSO ENCOURAGED TO COME BACK TO THE SITE ON THEIR OWN TO SHOW THEIR FAMILY HOW THEIR TREES HAVE GROWN, HOW THE STAND HAS CHANGED OVER TIME, AND WITNESS GOOD LAND STEWARDSHIP INACTION. EACH CHILD IS GIVEN A METAL TAG AND STAKE TO PERMANENTLY IDENTIFY THE TREES THEY PLANT. THE ROSS ROE MEMORIAL TREE PLANT HAS AN IMPRESSIVE 90% TREE SURVIVAL RATING, AND THEREFORE HAS BEEN EXTREMELY SUCCESSFUL IN RE-FORESTING THE PARCEL AND REDUCING THE HAZARDOUS FUEL LOADING FOR WILDFIRE NEXT TO ADJACENT BLM LANDS.

IMPLEMENT AN EARLY DETECTION RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR) PROGRAM TO MANAGE INVASIVE WEEDS IN AND AROUND THE HOLIDAY FARM FIRE. THE EDRR PROGRAM WILL RELY ON ONLINE TOOLS, (I.E., IMAPINVASIVES AND WEEDMAPPER), TO COLLECT AND MANAGE DATA. THE INTENT IS TO USE ESTABLISHED TOOLS TO SUPPORT THIS PROGRAM THAT CAN BE EASILY ACCESSED BY A WIDE RANGE OF PARTNERS. THESE PROGRAMS WILL ALSO HELP SUPPORT COORDINATION AND DATA SHARING WITH FEDERAL LAND MANAGERS SUCH AS THE BLM AND USFS. ALONG WITH PURE WATER PARTNERS' (PWP) MEMBER ORGANIZATIONS, THE PROGRAM ANTICIPATES CLOSE COORDINATION WITH A WIDE RANGE OF PARTNERS INCLUDING THE BLM, LANE COUNTY, AND MULTIPLE LOCAL UTILITIES WITH RIGHT-OF-WAY (ROW) CORRIDORS.THE PROJECT WILL SURVEY PRIORITY AREAS WITHIN THE HFF PERIMETER BY PWP MEMBERS, INCLUDING 200+ PRIVATE PARCELS BELONGING TO LANDOWNERS CURRENTLY ENGAGED WITH PWP. SURVEY EFFORTS WILL ALSO BE FOCUSED ON NON-FEDERAL PUBLIC LANDS INCLUDING LANE COUNTY, BLUE RIVER PARK, AND CONSERVATION LANDS MANAGED BY THE MRT. THE PWP WILL ALSO RELY ON MRT'S VOLUNTEER PROGRAM TO TRAIN AND MANAGE VOLUNTEERS TO CONDUCT NOXIOUS WEED SURVEYS ON MACKENZIE RIVER TRUST (MRT) LANDS AND SELECT PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS WHERE ACCESS IS LOGISTICALLY FEASIBLE. THE MRT VOLUNTEER PROGRAM HAS A DEDICATED MANAGER AND AN ESTABLISHED TRACK RECORD OF RECRUITING AND RETAINING DEDICATED VOLUNTEERS FROM A RANGE OF BACKGROUNDS. SURVEY EFFORTS WILL TARGET ASSESSING 200 ACRES IN 2021 AND 250 ACRES IN 2022.
